meaning_mnemonic:
This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. It repeats what comes before it.

To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a <radical>drop</radical> of water dripping into a <radical>prison</radical>. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again, driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over.
meaning_hint: Since this kanji doesn't really have a meaning as much as it does a function, try to change the way you think about it when you're memorizing it.
reading_mnemonic:
This symbol doesn't really have a name, but it's sometimes called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way:

Your mom is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling "<reading>No ma</reading>!" (のま) but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track, never stopping, repeating forever.
reading_hint: If you feel like you're so full you're about to burst, and if you imagine your mom doing this to you (how could you, ma?), you should be able to remember the reading of this kanji. That being said, the reading is mostly only useful in the event that you have to identify a 々 — otherwise, you won't see it much.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>street</kanji>.
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical street, you know the kanji street.
reading_mnemonic: So you're walking down this <kanji>street</kanji>, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the <kanji>street</kanji>-woman, Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう).
reading_hint: Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> is a character you'll see a lot throughout WaniKani, anytime the reading is ちょう like this one. A lore will develop around her, so the more vividly you can imagine your Mrs. Chou right now, the easier things will get later. In general, she's a mean, evil woman, so as long as you imagine her within those parameters, you're good. And, when I say she is a "street-woman" in the mnemonic, I don't mean she is homeless. She has a nice, middle-class home that's not outside of her financial means. What I'm saying is she wanders the streets looking for evil things to do. These are HER streets. So whenever you see the street radical, know that Mrs. Chou is probably going to show up!

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <reading>middle</reading> and the kanji <kanji>middle</kanji> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
meaning_hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise you might find yourself in the middle of a kanji-learning problem.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word Chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory.

If you remember back to the radical 中, a stick was stuck in the middle of the mouth of something. Let's say it was your mouth, and when you look up to see who did it, there stands <reading>Chew</reading>bacca. He's even doing his Chewbacca yell. And it isn't a stick in your mouth, it's an arrow from his bowcaster. It just so happens Chewbacca's bowcaster looks just like this kanji too. Go figure.
reading_hint: Imagine the fear and shock you'd feel after finding out it was Chewbacca who shot the middle of your mouth (and head). Touch his fur. Look really close at his weapon. Give him a sniff, too. Just so that memory never fades away.

vocabulary.meaning: Middle Ten Days Of The Month

meaning_mnemonic: What's something with <radical>nine</radical> sides? Just add a <radical>drop</radical> and you'll have something that's almost a <kanji>circle</kanji>.
meaning_hint: It's not quite a <kanji>circle</kanji> though. You just need to add a <radical>drop</radical> of liquid to the edges to smooth it out to become a full circle.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worth while. When you think about a circle, think about Maru all rolled up in a little circle, being super adorable. Don't tell me it doesn't melt your heart just thinking about it. Alternatively, you could also look at this kanji and think of Maru inside of a box, with his little tail sticking out of it. Whatever works best for you, just get yourself to "Maru."
reading_hint: Obviously if you "don't know this reading" well enough, you should watch some more Maru videos. I'll understand... just make sure you come back someday, okay?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>five</radical> radical and the <kanji>five</kanji> kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, friend-o.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Five</kanji> is the number of buildings <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) will knock down. Oh, look! There he goes now.
reading_hint: One, two, three, four, five—GODZILLA IS HERE GO GO, RUN!

meaning_mnemonic: Just imagine a beast with a <radical>lid</radical> for a head and <radical>fins</radical> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <kanji>six</kanji> is the devil's number.
meaning_hint: Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (<kanji>six</kanji>), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.
reading_mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word <reading>rock</reading>. 

So, think about the devil and the devil's number. What is often associated with those things? Why, <reading>rock</reading> (ろく) and roll is. Imagine the lid-head fin-legged beast suddenly blasting out rock music in the middle of his destructive mayhem.
reading_hint: Sing along with the monster, if it helps you to remember the reading of this kanji.

meaning_mnemonic: The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The <radical>lid</radical> is inside the <radical>head</radical> for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <kanji>yen</kanji> coins, the currency of Japan!
meaning_hint: Another thing that will help is to associate the word <kanji>round</kanji> to this kanji, because it has both of these meanings. Both are right, and if you learn one that's better than not learning either, but maybe if you think about how round the coins themselves are inside this person's head, you'll remember this one too.
reading_mnemonic: What does the word <kanji>yen</kanji> sound like? It sounds like <reading>えん</reading>. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん!
reading_hint: Picture these <kanji>round</kanji> えん in your mind. Maybe look some up online too, just to be safe.

meaning_mnemonic: There are two <radical>mountains</radical> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <kanji>exit</kanji> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.
meaning_hint: In your imagination, really feel like your life depends on getting out. The important part is the feeling of "needing to get out of the mountain pass." If you have this feeling, you'll be more likely to remember that this kanji means exit, because that's what you want to do when you see this kanji.
reading_mnemonic: As you're trying to <kanji>exit</kanji> this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he <reading>shoots you</reading> (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.
reading_hint: Focus on the surprise of realizing you're being hunted while trying to find the exit to the mountain range, then focus on the next part, where you get shot. View it in your head as the hunter shooting you. Powww!

vocabulary.meaning: To Go Out Into The World

meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is <radical>sword</radical>, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese <kanji>sword</kanji>? That's right, the most common is a <kanji>katana</kanji>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
meaning_hint: This kanji also looks a lot like the kanji 力. To avoid getting them confused, remember that this one is missing the little nubbin at the top, because 90% of the power comes from the sword to cut your enemies down (which is why the sword kanji is 90% of the power kanji).
reading_mnemonic: So now you have this sweet <kanji>katana</kanji> in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to <reading>とう</reading>きょう (Tokyo). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to travel to とうきょう with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. I hope you don't have any other swords hidden anywhere.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember.
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical <radical>thousand</radical> then you know the kanji <kanji>thousand</kanji> as well!
reading_mnemonic: Remember the thousand people going down the slide on a cross in the radical 千? Turns out each one of them was carrying a <kanji>thousand</kanji> <reading>cen</reading>ts (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what a thousand times a thousand cents would come out to. It's quite a lot, actually.
reading_hint: Problem is, as they all tumble down the slide the change falls out of their pockets, so there's a thousand times a thousand cents scattered all over on the floor under the slide.

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Narwhal</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s are on the <kanji>right</kanji> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.

See how the "mouth" radical is to the right of the "narwhal" radical? That should help you remember that this means <kanji>right</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine looking at a narwhal from the front. No mouth. Now look at it from the right. Mouth!
reading_mnemonic: How did we know to look from the <kanji>right</kanji>, though? Because the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) figured it out. Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side.
reading_hint:
Imagine a bunch of youths walking in a group and looking at everything from the right. You remember when you were a youth and you used to look at everything from one side too.

Note: All the ゆう readings will use the word "youths" for the reading mnemonic. You can think of these "youths" as a group of younger people who cause a lot of the problems in this world.

meaning_mnemonic: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <radical>legs</radical> end up inside your <radical>mouth</radical>. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <kanji>four</kanji> sides.
meaning_hint: If you can get to square, you should be able to get to four as well, since squares always have four sides.
reading_mnemonic: This amazing feat, which turned you into a <kanji>four</kanji> sided square, has you looking like a four sided animal: the <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Look at yourself in the mirror and see an adorable four-sided sheep looking back at you. (You can't see the other sides because mirrors aren't 3D and whatnot. So you're a bit cartoonish.)
reading_hint: What's better than one four sided sheep?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> radical and the <kanji>dirt</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical dirt, you know the kanji dirt.
reading_mnemonic: Who spends a lot of time in <kanji>dirt</kanji>? <reading>Do</reading>gs (ど) do! Dogs dig in dirt, they roll in dirt, sometimes they try to eat dirt (which isn't so great).
reading_hint: Dogs and dirt just go together!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>evening</radical> radical and the <kanji>evening</kanji> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.
meaning_hint: Do what you're meant to do. Study those radicals!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>evening</kanji> is when all the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) come outside to play.
reading_hint:
Young people love staying up the entire evening doing youth-people things, and it's really obnoxious for us curmudgeonly folk.

Note: All the ゆう readings will use the word "youths" as a keyword for the mnemonic, so bear that in mind for any future ゆう reading you'll encounter.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>heaven</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>heaven</kanji>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
meaning_hint: If you know your radicals well (and you should!) you know the meaning of this kanji well, as well!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Heaven</kanji>... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only <reading>ten</reading> (てん) percent!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in line to get into heaven. You're super worried, because you're not sure if you'll get in. You heard there was a one in <reading>ten</reading> chance... those aren't good odds. Feel nervous in your imagination. Feel worried. Feel the pressure as you get closer and closer to the gate... will you make it?? Ten percent!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>child</radical> radical and the <kanji>child</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the sounds  し and す we'll use these mnemonics:

There is a <kanji>child</kanji> standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in a <reading>su</reading>it (す) in front of you. You yelp, blink, and it's back to being a child. Are... all children really just sheep in suits?!
reading_hint: The child runs away and you chase after it. Every time it's about to turn a corner it looks like a sheep in a suit again, but whenever you yell and point, it turns back. You're the only one who can see this sheep suit child!!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>small</radical> radical and the <kanji>small</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: Knowing radicals sure is nice, huh?
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>small</kanji> kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the <kanji>little</kanji> kanji represents all of that.
reading_hint: You read that right, shougun is written with a long う sound. Make sure you spell it right from now on!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Narwhal</radical>s do <radical>construction</radical> with their <kanji>left</kanji> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!
meaning_hint: Picture a bunch of narwhals constructing an underwater ice village. They're all working away with their left hands.
reading_mnemonic: In their <kanji>left</kanji> hands, the narwhals all hold <reading>saw</reading>s (さ). That's because the ice for their homes is already there, so they just need to saw away at them to make the shapes they want. Narwhal construction is actually very simple.
reading_hint: If you're right-handed, imagine trying to use these left-handed saws. It flips and flops all over until you drop it. But if you're left-handed it feels just right!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hand</radical> radical and the <kanji>hand</kanji> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!
meaning_hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. It won't be forever that radicals and kanji overlap so nicely like this!
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading て we will use the word "television." You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little <reading>te</reading>levisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.
reading_hint: You try to shake your hands off, but it's no good. The televisions are stuck, and the volume won't go down. You have no idea how you got these televisions on your hands. All you know is that you want them off right this instant.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> you put <radical>barb</radical>s at the bottom of a <radical>slide</radical>. This is your special <kanji>talent</kanji>. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself placing the barbs in front of the slide, thinking about how talented you are. It took years of training to perfect this talent. But it was worth it. Everyone on the playground respects you now.
reading_mnemonic: But then people start to say that no human could have so much <kanji>talent</kanji>, that you must be a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). Are you really a talented cyborg?
reading_hint: Cyborgs have brain implants and cool bionic limbs, so they're basically the most talented people around.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>writing</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>writing</kanji> as well.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
reading_mnemonic:
This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You always put <kanji>writing</kanji> on your <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん) to keep them from getting eaten by the bun <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん). What kind of writing? Usually it's just an X to show the monster these buns are off-limits. (In fact, it kind of looks like the X part in 文. Hmm…)
reading_hint: Imagine writing a big X (or even a big 文) on all your buns, then showing them to the bun monster. Watch as he turns and goes at the sight of the writing, all disappointed. Not today, bun monster.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> radical and <kanji>sun</kanji> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <kanji>day</kanji> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
meaning_hint: The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!
reading_mnemonic:
There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. 

The <kanji>sun</kanji> is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (にち), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.
reading_hint:
This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth.

Also note that there's another reading worth learning as well: じつ. The reading can be remembered by thinking "<reading>Gee! Two</reading> readings?" Because, seriously, two readings? Too many...

vocabulary.reading: おたんじょうびおめでとう

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> kanji is made up of the <radical>moon</radical> radical. This kanji is also used to mean <kanji>month</kanji>.
meaning_hint: This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> really <reading>gets</reading> (げつ) to your <reading>guts</reading> (がつ). Staring at the moon for too long will give you terrible indigestion, so be careful!
reading_hint:
Use the げつ reading when this kanji means "moon", in words like "moonlight". Use げつ for counting months, and saying things like "last month and "next month", too. Go for がつ in the names of months, like "January".

Don't worry too much about memorizing this pattern, though. You'll be getting lots of practice soon!

meaning_mnemonic: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <radical>tree</radical> and <kanji>tree</kanji> are the same in looks and meaning.
meaning_hint: So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?
reading_mnemonic: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to <reading>mock</reading> (もく) you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground.
reading_hint: Feel the shame, feel the irritation. Make yourself want to run away from those dumb trees that are mocking you.

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>book</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>book</kanji> as well.

Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <kanji>origin</kanji>, <kanji>real</kanji>, and <kanji>main</kanji>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo! And good luck with all the meanings (sorry sorry sorry).
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Book</kanji>s are one of the best ways to <reading>hone</reading> (ほん) your intellect, you know?
reading_hint: Just think about books and how you use them to hone your skills. Or read a book about honing things. Like swords.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a line on the <radical>ground</radical> so you <radical>stop</radical>, making a giant sign pop up that says <kanji>CORRECT</kanji>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.
meaning_hint: Imagine walking, staring at the ground until you come across a line that you're supposed to stop at. If you stop, the big "correct" sign appears, chiming a happy tune.
reading_mnemonic: You did the <kanji>correct</kanji> thing, so here's your reward: a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) from the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) himself!
reading_hint: Perhaps a slightly unorthodox weapon for a ruler of medieval Japan, but you won't complain about a saber from the Shogun himself!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>water</radical> radical and the <kanji>water</kanji> kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of <kanji>water</kanji>). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very <reading>swee</reading>t. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).
reading_hint: I know that was a long one, but try to imagine all the different bits. Try to feel the feelings (cold, smell, etc) too. The more you create in this fake memory (which you’re using to remember and associate water with すい (swing)) the more likely you are to end up remembering enough to make it happen. Especially when it comes to the senses part, the more vividly you imagined it, the more likely you are to remember the on’yomi.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fire</radical> radical and the <kanji>fire</kanji> kanji are the same as each other.
meaning_hint: If you know the radicals then this one is EZPZ.
reading_mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word <reading>car</reading>.

For this kanji, when we think <kanji>fire</kanji>, we ought to think of something on fire. What's on fire? It's obviously your very own <reading>car</reading> (か)! Oh Goddd NOOO!
reading_hint: Oh no... Oh no!! If you don't have a <reading>car</reading>, imagine what it'd feel like if your car just exploded and burned down. If you do have a car, imagine your own car in this situation. It should be a terrible feeling, if you imagine it well enough. So, when you think <kanji>fire</kanji>, remember the fear you had when your car was given to the flames. Now you have to walk everywhere, sad :(

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dog</radical> radical and <kanji>dog</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Soon there will be very few kanji/radical-same combos ... so enjoy it while you can.
reading_mnemonic: Every <kanji>dog</kanji> likes to <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>noo</reading>dles (いぬ). Like that movie where the dogs share a noodle and end up kissing, right? So when you see 犬, just imagine how those two eat noodles.
reading_hint: P.S. Don't actually let your dog eat noodles, at least not with marinara sauce. Disney didn't show you how that Lady and Tramp date probably ended — unromantically, with indigestion.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> has a big <radical>drop</radical> of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a <kanji>ball</kanji>.
meaning_hint: This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a <kanji>ball</kanji>, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the <kanji>ball</kanji>) over and over again. Kanji are surprisingly playful like that.
reading_mnemonic: When he's done playing with it, the king gives his <kanji>ball</kanji> to <reading>Tama</reading>ra (たま), the resident ball girl, for safekeeping.
reading_hint: Try to remember Tamara the ball girl. She'll come up anytime the reading for a kanji is たま, and usually she'll be involved with some kind of ball or round object. That's her job, after all.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> radical and the <kanji>king</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: Hopefully you're a king of radicals... because if you are, this kanji was super easy for you!
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>king</kanji> you need to say, "<reading>Oh</reading> (おう) King! Oh King, oh no, oh why are you looking at me like that? Oh King... you aren't going to chop off my head are you? OH NO!"
reading_hint:
You need to be polite when you talk to the king and add "Oh" to the beginning, otherwise the king will be pretty angry and bad things might happen.

We're going to use the 王 kanji for all おう mnemonics from now on. So make sure you always remember to say おう King!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice paddy</radical> radical and the <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
meaning_hint: Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco."

You're in the rice field... but when you lean down to examine the rice more closely, you see that it's not rice that's growing, it's a bunch of little <reading>ta</reading>cos (た), blossoming out of the ground.
reading_hint: Smell the tacos. Touch the tacos. Taste the tacos. This is definitely a very strange rice field.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>white</radical> and the kanji <kanji>white</kanji> are the same.
meaning_hint: Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>white</kanji> team was the first to be able to <reading>hack</reading> (はく) the <kanji>white</kanji> iPhone.
reading_hint: Imagine two teams (black and <kanji>white</kanji>), wearing their team colors, working really hard on hacking the iPhone. It is a huge contest, and people are watching with a lot of tension, to see who will hack the <kanji>white</kanji> iPhone first. Feel that tension, and see the colors separating them so vividly. The colors are important, and the excitement of the winner holding up the <reading>hack</reading>ed iPhone is too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> radical and <kanji>eye</kanji> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
meaning_hint: Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study their radicals.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>eyes</kanji> are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "<reading>Mehhhhhh</reading> (め)!"
reading_hint: Of course, feel the pain of your eye being gone... and struggle to get it back. You eventually give up because the sheep is too fast, but then you come up with an idea. What if I call out back to the sheep in its own language? Go ahead and cover one eye and start making "MEHHH" noises to see if you can get the sheep to come back to you and give you your eye. It's up to you whether it works or not, but be sure to feel frustrated by its reaction, or happy by it. Either one works.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>stand</radical> and the kanji <kanji>stand</kanji> are the same thing, so now you know them both.
meaning_hint: If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!
reading_mnemonic: Think of someone who has to <kanji>stand</kanji> up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the <reading>Ritz</reading> (りつ).
reading_hint: Imagine the doormen being extra straight… too straight in their standing. On their uniform is “The Ritz” written in fine lettering, and as you walk past them, they stand up straight and say “Welcome to the Ritz!” Whatever you do, while you’re thinking about it, make sure you think about how they stand up so straight, and associate it with these doormen, who work, specifically, at the Ritz. If you effectively imagine all this, you should be able to remember this on’yomi. Go through it like it’s a movie in your head!
